sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Congestive heart failure, Acutely decompensated - Dyspnea: 2 mcg/kg IV bolus followed by 0.01 mcg/kg/min continuous IV infusion; bolus may not be appropriate for patients with systolic blood pressure below 110 mmHg or if recently treated with afterload reducers; reduce dose or discontinue therapy if hypotension occurs; may restart at a 30% lower dose (no bolus) after the patient is stabilized
  • Congestive heart failure, Acutely decompensated - Dyspnea: titration, may increase by 0.005 mcg/kg/min (after a bolus of 1 mcg/kg IV) no more frequently than every 3 hours up to a MAX dose of 0.03 mcg/kg/min

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: no dosage adjustment required
  • hypotension: reduce dose or discontinue therapy; may restart at 30% reduced dose (no bolus) once patient is stable

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Congestive heart failure, Acutely decompensated - Dyspnea

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• cardiogenic shock
  • hypersensitivity to nesiritide or any component of the product
  • systolic blood pressure less than 100 mmHg prior to therapy, persistent; increased risk of symptomatic hypotension

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cardiac output dependent upon venous return; use not recommended
  • cardiomyopathy, restrictive or obstructive; use not recommended
  • heart failure, severe, in which renal function may depend on the activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system; risk of azotemia
  • hypersensitivity/allergic reactions, serious, have been reported; drug discontinuation recommended if reaction occurs
  • hypotension has been reported; dose reduction or drug discontinuation may be necessary
  • low cardiac filling pressures, suspected; use not recommended
  • pericardial tamponade; use not recommended
  • pericarditis, constrictive; use not recommended
  • renal function, decreased (increased serum creatinine), may occur; monitoring recommended
  • sensitivity to recombinant peptides, history; increased risk of hypersensitivity/allergic reaction
  • valvular stenosis, significant; use not recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypotension (4% to 17%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (3%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (2%), Headache (7%)
  • Renal:Serum creatinine raised (17% to 31.4%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Injection site extravasation
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Other:Death, Increased risk

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Human BNP increases intracellular concentrations of guanosine 3'5'-cyclic monophosphate (cGMP) and smooth muscle cell relaxation by binding to the particulate guanylate cyclase receptor of vascular smooth muscle and endothelial cells. Cyclic GMP serves as a second messenger to dilate veins and arteries. In human studies in patients with heart failure, nesiritide has been shown to reduce pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (in a dose-dependent manner) and systemic arterial pressure.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IV use only
  • Intravenous
    • reconstitute vial (1.5 mg) by adding 5 mL of diluent (D5W, NS, or D5-0.45% NaCl) from a pre-filled 250 mL IV plastic bag and rock vial gently, do not shake; withdraw contents and add to 250 mL IV plastic bag (6 mcg/mL)
    • use reconstituted solutions within 24 hours
    • prime IV tubing with an infusion of 5 mL of solution prior to connecting IV port or administering bolus or infusion
    • bolus must be drawn from the prepared infusion bag and administered over approximately 60 seconds through IV port in the tubing
    • following bolus, infuse at rate of 0.1 mL/kg/hr
    • flush catheter between administration of incompatible drugs
    • do not administer through a central heparin-coated catheter

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduced pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and improvement in short term (3 hours) symptoms of dyspnea are indicative of efficacy
  • serum creatinine; during and after completion of therapy; continue to monitor increased levels until stabilized
  • blood pressure; closely during administration

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
NESIRITIDE
OVERDOSE: Information is limited. Excessive hypotension is the anticipated effect following overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Hypotension, bradycardia, nausea and vomiting, insomnia, dizziness and anxiety occurred with greater frequency following nesiritide therapy during clinical trials as compared with patients in the control group.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
NESIRITIDE
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. There is no known antidote available for overdose.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl, dopamine, norepinephrine.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs and renal function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
NESIRITIDE
TOXICITY: A specific toxic dose has not been established. A 3-year-old child, with decompensated cardiac failure, received an 18-fold overdose of nesiritide (36 mcg/kg) as an IV bolus dose. The patient did not develop any hemodynamic, cardiovascular or renal adverse effects following the overdose. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: The recommended adult dose is 2 mcg/kg IV bolus followed by 0.01 mcg/kg/min continuous IV infusion.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause hypotension, headache, nausea, and back pain.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of hypotension.
